questions.question_text:
A technician is setting up a projector for a videoconferencing system. When the user attempts to connect a laptop to the system, the system displays the following error message: no source found
The user tries multiple cables and inputs on the projector. Which of the following should the user try NEXT?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
If you are ever being asked what to do NEXT or FIRST when troubleshooting, completely replacing the hardware is almost NEVER the correct answer.

Selected Answer: B
the answer is B
This ensures tht the laptop is outputting a signal to the projector. often the error No source found occurs because the laptop is not configured to send a signal to the external display.

comments.content: No doubt its poorly worded however the question is asking "when the user connect laptop to "SYSTEM" (when it should says display or projector). The laptop is not having issue its the projector or display that is not showing input source. So in this case answer B is the correct answer and display or projector needs to be checked.

No source found means either the settings of the projectors are not set to the right source, or the laptop is not streaming to the projector. Extending or duplicating would therefor display to the projector.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Worded poorly, Option B is not correct and D seems to extreme. 
I am hung up on "No Source Found".
Extending/Duplicating the display would not do anything due to the projector not even detecting input from any cable. So by my process of elimination, "D" would be the most correct answer.
If the graphics card was bad, you would not see an image on your laptop either, right? Am I wrong?

Also, If the option of D had added "might have gone bad" then it would be a good candidate of choice but it didn't say so and also made the statement conclusive. That alone should make the answer "B" a standalone option.
I believe the correct answer should have been "D" but based on ComptTIA steps the right answer in this analogy is "B".

comments.content: Main rule: try the least invasive thing first.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Via CompTIA "If no image is displayed on the monitor or projector, first make sure that the display device is plugged in and turned on. Check that the monitor is not in standby mode (press a key or cycle the power to the monitor to activate it).

You may also need to use controls on the monitor itself to adjust the image or select the appropriate data source or input channel. For example, if there is no image on the screen, check that the monitor is set to use the HDMI port that the computer is connected to, rather than an empty DVI port. These o n-screen display (OSD) menus are operated using buttons on the monitor case. As well as input control, you can usually find settings for brightness, color/contrast, and power saving."

comments.content: It might be D.The question states that the user has already tried multiple inputs on the projector. Which means that the next step is to replace the graphics card

choices.A: Check the bulb on the projector and replace it with a new one.
choices.B: Check the display settings on the computer and set them to extend/duplicate.
choices.C: Replace the projector with another known-good one and try again.
choices.D: Replace the video card on the machine that is plugged in to the projector, as it has gone bad.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a method that can be used to securely connect a remote user's laptop to a corporate server?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Via CompTIA:

"Internet services are placed in protected screened subnets, which represent a border between the private LAN and the public Internet. Traffic to and from this zone is strictly filtered and monitored. Network border services provide Internet access for employees, email and communications, remote access and WAN branch office links via virtual private networks (VPNs), and web services for external clients and customers."
B: VPN

questions.question_text: A technician is inspecting a projector that is displaying fuzzy images. Which of the following actions would provide the BEST solution?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is ðŸ’¯

Based on the symptoms described, the BEST solution would be to reseat the lamp. Fuzzy images can be caused by a variety of issues, but a common cause is a lamp that is not securely seated or is nearing the end of its life. By reseating the lamp, the technician can ensure that it is properly connected and providing sufficient light to produce a clear image.

Adjusting the lens might help if the image is out of focus, but if the image is fuzzy, it is likely that the lamp is the root cause of the issue. Changing the filter and replacing the video cable may help if those components are faulty, but they are less likely to be the cause of fuzzy images than an improperly seated or failing lamp.

Selected Answer: A
Per CompTIA if the projector throws a fuzzy image, the lens might be dirty or out of focus (if its focus is adjustable). All in all adjusting or cleaning the lens should be a good way to go.

Selected Answer: B
B. Tablet/PC settings

A technician should check the tablet/PC settings as this is likely to be the cause of the touch-screen features not working. Windows devices have built-in settings for touch-screen features, such as the sensitivity and touch mode. Checking these settings can help determine if there are any configuration changes that could have resulted in the touch-screen features not working. The technician should go to the Control Panel and look for a section on the tablet/PC settings. Here, the technician can adjust the touch-screen settings and calibrate the touch screen, if necessary. If the touch-screen settings are correct, the technician may need to look into other issues, such as a hardware failure or software glitch.

Selected Answer: B
Cool answer

questions.question_text: An end user discovered that the touch-screen features on a Windows device have stopped working. Which of the following should a technician check?

choices.A: Upgrade the Ethernet cable to the latest specification.

comments.content: Agreed- An unmanaged switch doesn't provide Power over Ethernet (PoE), which is required for the IP phone to have power.
That is not entirely correct. There are such things as unmanaged switches that provide PoE
remember that it asked for the quickest way

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer.
A,B,C all require sourcing new parts/devices. Changing ports is the quickest

comments.content: However, it doesn't power on, so changing the switch port wouldn't do anything. C is the only correct answer, as that would provide the power the phone needs to boot.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I like D because out there are unmanage switchs with poe ports and regular ports separated

Selected Answer: C
If the switch isn't a PoE switch, it isn't going to magically become one by changing ports. It also is not necessarily a slower solution either assuming you have a PoE injector on hand and do not need to purchase one.

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
The answer is C
IP phones typically require Power of Ethernet to function and an unmanaged switch may not support PoE

Selected Answer: C
Based on what everyone else has already said, C makes the most sense as the phone requires PoE.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
It needs to be powered

comments.content: But actually, considering how CompTIA wants you to think, it probably is D. If they're using VoIP, they probably have switches with PoE capabilities. Lots of assumptions, but eh.
Don't overthink, device doesn't boot, logical cause is it doesn't get power, logical answer it needs power. D needs too many other variables to know if it works, so C is the answer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The question asks for the QUICKEST way to RESOLVE this issue. It is a unmanaged switch in a SOHO and IP phones need POE to boot. We do not know if the switch has other ports capable of POE, but due to the environment it is in and type of switch, it very well may not. Disregarding that fact, the only answer out of the given choices, that guarantees the QUICKIEST and RESOLUTION (resolves), is a POE injector. Changing ports does not guarantee it will actually RESOLVE the issue, but it does fulfill the QUICKIEST, but thats not what the question asks.

Selected Answer: D
The question asks for the QUICKEST solution.

Yes C might be the best quick solution but all A,B,C answers require sourcing parts whereas D is literally moving one wire on a switch. If that doesn't work you can escalate it to get parts.

Therefore D is the QUICKEST option there

comments.content: An IT department most likely would have the required parts and would be just as fast. If D doesn't work, you still will have to do C, making D not quicker than C. With C you're guaranteed the solution works.
Hey, but if D works, you wouldn't have to deal with C and therefore the quickest will be D.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Assuming that the phone requires power, POE injector answers this.
Changing ports allows for another port that is set up for PoE, maybe a different VLAN, I dunno. I have to think that you would hope that the switch and power supply have anough juice to power the phone, sometimes too many phones for the switch to power, so the PoE injector would be the answer, but then again Im drunk so.....
YES the right answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
Unmanaged Power over Ethernet (PoE) switches are basic plug-and-play devices with no remote configuration, management, or monitoring options. Antaira offers a full line of industrial unmanaged PoE switches that boast a variety of port-count, speed (including 10Gigabit), mounting, and fiber.

I say, C because IP phone requires POE and switching ports is very unlikely to fix the issue as they are all likely to be in the same state and we were not told that the Switch had POE capability which an IP phone requires.

Quickest way to resolve this issue** Taking the cable out and putting it into a new port to may be get the phone to boot sounds like a waste of time. Also we know the phone needs *PoE*.. So if we look at the possible answers, only ONE is a guarantee to work immediately and that would be C. (We don't even know if the Unmanaged switch has PoE capabilities)
There are unmanaged switches with both normal ports and PoE ports. Switching ports is the quickest way to resolve the issue.

Selected Answer: D
Both C and D are good answers however, the question asks what the quickest action is. Therefore the answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
Unmanaged switchâ€™s has POE

Selected Answer: D
IP phones require power over Ethernet (PoE) to function. If the phone is not booting, it is possible that the switch is not providing PoE. The quickest way to resolve this issue is to try a different port on the switch. If the phone boots on a different port, then the problem is with the original port.

Selected Answer: D
I was really confused about C and D as the details are not really helpful. 
Unmanaged switches are famous to be basic lan mangers that trats multivast in the same way of broadcast. They basically do not have PoE on them however several models are equpped with PoE (normally, the model number has a letter "P" at the end).

We don`t know here which modek we have got or what port is the phone connected. 
However, in case of doubt, would be silly to buy a PoE injector while there might be potentially some PoE enabled ports. Just try to connect to other ports first and, and then , if unsuccesful, go and buy an injector. The keyword here is QUICKEST.

Selected Answer: D
Unmanaged switches very often have PoE ports, after all home users have IP surveillance cameras, access points, etc. that need PoE. But often not all of the ports on the switch are PoE. So it could just be connected to a non-PoE port. The QUICKEST way to resolve is to try switching to another port. Installing a PoE injector is not necessarily quick, what if you don't have one on hand?

Selected Answer: C
Following the Troubleshooting Methodology 
2. Establish a theory of probable cause (question the obvious)
First thing to do here would be plugging it to different port to test if it is actually works. Hence Quickest way to resolve would be just pluging in a PoE injector

The quickest way to resolve this issue is to install a PoE injector. The problem is likely that the switch is not providing power over Ethernet to the phone, which is necessary for the phone to boot. By installing a PoE injector, the technician can provide power to the phone without having to replace the switch or upgrade the Ethernet cable.

Replacing the phone or upgrading the Ethernet cable are unlikely to solve the problem, as the issue is with the lack of power being supplied to the phone. Changing ports on the switch may help if the original port was faulty, but it is less likely to be the cause of the problem than a lack of PoE.

Selected Answer: D
Some unmanaged switches have PoE and non PoE ports. Changing that is quick

Selected Answer: D
Key word, QUICKEST
D is fastest. The port could be the issue. Unmanaged switches do have PoE if the phone needs PoE.

Selected Answer: D
D is the quickest solution

Selected Answer: D
PoE-enabled switches are the most common type of PSE that is used with IP phones. With such a switch, a single network device provides both power and network connectivity, making implementation simple and easy

Selected Answer: C
https://intellinetnetwork.eu/pages/what-is-a-poe-injector

comments.content: That information is not given in the question. It simply states the phone does not boot.

discussion.content: Answer is D. PoE is not necessary because phone can power on

questions.question_text: A help desk technician has been tasked with installing an IP phone in a small office with an unmanaged switch. When connected to an RJ45 receptacle, the phone does not boot. Which of the following is the QUICKEST way to resolve this issue?
